s1: This course provides a broad but thorough introduction to the methods and practice of statistical machine learning.
s2: The lectures will also address recent literature describing advances in operating systems.

s1: Topics covered will include Bayesian inference and maximum likelihood modeling; regression, classification, density estimation, clustering, principal and independent component analysis; parametric, semi-parametric, and non-parametric models; basis functions, neural networks, kernel methods, and graphical models; deterministic and stochastic optimisation; overfitting, regularisation, and validation.
s2: The following topics are addressed: system programming and its facilities (including I/O, signals, job control, interprocess communication, sockets, transport layers, remote operations), system calls and their relation to the system libraries, process management and coordination, implementation of message passing, memory management, interrupt handling, real-time clocks, device-independent input/output, serial-line drivers, network communication, disk drivers, deadlock avoidance, scheduling paradigms, file systems, security.

s1: Describe a number of models for supervised, unsupervised, and reinforcement machine learning.
s2: define and analyse the structure of operating systems in general, especially those that support communicating processes.

s1: Assess the strength and weakness of each of these models.
s2: identify and describe the reasons for many architectural features of contemporary machines.

s1: Interpret the mathematical equations from Linear Algebra, Statistics, and Probability Theory used in these machine learning models.
s2: describe and analyse the actual algorithms and data structures that are used in a particular operating system.

s1: Implement efficient machine learning algorithms on a computer.
s2: describe and analyse the actual algorithms and data structures that are used in a particular operating system.

s1: Design test procedures in order to evaluate a model.
s2: demonstrate experience in the design and implementation of a large software system.

s1: Combine several models in order to gain better results.
s2: identify and evaluate features of the system library of a particular operating system, and be able to apply this knowledge to program small applications.

s1: Make choices for a model for new machine learning tasks based on reasoned argument.
s2: identify and evaluate features of the system library of a particular operating system, and be able to apply this knowledge to program small applications.
